posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
Thought it was worth putting out there that Onshape now has a native dark mode as part of the 1.184 release.

image 1589×882 98.2 KB

image 1589×882 98.2 KB

image 1589×882 98.2 KB

If you click your name in the top right corner, a “View in dark mode” slider is in the menu. To make it permanent, click your name → My account → Preferences → Theming.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
The most important feature!

Edit:

Save energy. Dark mode should be the default theme developers set. While it’s not a huge savings think about how many users might be using the software. That small 3-9% adds up when you are talking about thousands, perhaps millions of people using your software. The study below is also a few years out of date now, and about mobile devices, but still relevant in my opinion.

When Android and Apple operating system updates started giving users the option to put their smartphones in dark mode, the feature showed potential for saving the battery life of newer phones with screens that allow darker-colored pixels to use less...

Purdue researchers found that switching from light mode to dark mode saves only 3%-9% power on average for several different OLED smartphones.

When I say default theme there should still be choices absolutely. Dyslexic people have a more difficult time sometimes with dark mode so make sure to think about accessibility always. The article below is more recent and talks about accessibility which is often forgotten about. Bootstrap and Bootswatch for web design does support light or dark theme options in many cases so it’s worth looking into.

Learn how to add Dark Mode to your website design to make it more eco-friendly and easier to look at.

Estimated reading time: 5 minutes

For the best experience, visitors should be able to choose their own Light/Dark Mode preference.

link_counts.title: Dark mode may not save your phone’s battery life as much as you think, but there are a few silver linings - Purdue University News
Using Dark Mode to make your website more energy efficient - Root Web Design Studio

posts.name: Roger Moore
posts.cooked: Since you brought Onshape CAM up… are we close to a release?

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
General policy is to not discuss future releases so we don’t create disappointment when features take more time. This already happened with CAM, so I don’t want to speculate further. Sorry for the non-answer.

The CAM Studio EVP is going well and then feedback we’ve received is being implemented. Trust me, the second it drops, I’ll be here to discuss how to use it. I want to use it to make robot parts as much as everyone else!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I’ve been delaying (partially because I’m lazy) creating a Kiri:Moto in Onshape  tutorial for CNC routing because of the impending CAM.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
I can think of a bunch of missing features that are more important than dark mode:

mirrors in assemblies,

sketches & reference geometry in assemblies,

mates listed next to their parts in the tree,

dimensions that can reference other dimensions,

better search / filters of public documents and featurescripts,

URLs to link individual parts within part studios,

context menus that are more predictable,

“lightweight” mode for large assemblies,

an offline viewer,

yes CAM

But I’m getting OnShape for free, so I guess I can’t complain.  Yay I guess?

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
nuclearnerd:

I can think of a bunch of missing features that are more important than dark mode

I agree it’s not the most important, but it’s a QoL tool that I’ve seen brought up here a bunch. I wanted to make sure people knew it was a thing.

Onshape does a lot of parallel development and releases updates to different areas whenever they’re ready. Your list has a lot of great (and common) feedback:

nuclearnerd:

mirrors in assemblies

Yup. Known for a long time and currently being worked on.

nuclearnerd:

sketches & reference geometry in assemblies

You can insert sketches and other geometry elements into assemblies right now, but they do have to be created in a part studio beforehand. In-context part studios address some use cases, but creating sketches actually in the assembly is another known feature request.

nuclearnerd:

mates listed next to their parts in the tree

This, or highlighting the mates that involve a given component. H-key to turn on mate connector highlights helps but isn’t the full solve.

nuclearnerd:

dimensions that can reference other dimensions

You can create dependent/driven variables that reference the geometry you choose, and then you can feed those variables into other dimensions? May not be exactly what you mean, but feeding numbers from one area to another is easier as of recent updates.

nuclearnerd:

better search / filters of public documents and featurescripts

Couldn’t agree more. There’s a lot to consider about implementing this and related features, though - supporting public libraries, creating profile pages where models can be showcased, etc.

nuclearnerd:

URLs to link individual parts within part studios

I’ve not heard this one before. Derive it into its own part studio? Part Studios do have unique links, and if it’s in the same document it should live update.

nuclearnerd:

“lightweight” mode for large assemblies

Assembly performance in general is something that is always being addressed. I personally think it’s gotten better over the last few years.

nuclearnerd:

an offline viewer

Would be very cool!

Ultimately there’ll always be more to add and improve on, and getting this feedback is helpful. The Improvements Request forum gets monitored and tagged to issues/improvements regularly, and submitting things to our support channels does the same.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Drew_B:

nuclearnerd:

URLs to link individual parts within part studios

I’ve not heard this one before. Derive it into its own part studio? Part Studios do have unique links, and if it’s in the same document it should live update.

Let me try to explain this one:  Lets say our CAD Team wants to communicate to our Build Team that a certain part is ready for manufacturing.  We have a spreadsheet with part names, material requirements and status.  It would be really nice to copy-paste a link that takes you right to the part (and revision) in question.  Unfortunately the best you can do right now is link to the part studio and have them look up the part name in the Studio’s parts list.

When we used Solidworks, we would list the (single part per document) filename.  For OnShape where multi-part documents are common (and awesome), a dedicated URL for each part (click it and it opens the proper studio and highlights and/or “isolates” the part) would be very helpful.

Thank you for your responses!

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
This would be really slick, thanks for the explanation.

The workflow that 6329 has used for a while is that the designer does the necessary exports of the part (3MF, DXF) and that’s what gets handed off in the parts tracking sheet which circumvents this issue, which explains why I was a little lost. Some way to direct to a specific part would be nice.
